The lessons are still in English and I speak French but it's just kind of annoying and I was wondering if it was happening for anyone else or just me. Also wanted to know if there was a way to switch it.
Answer:
Try changing the preferred language list in your browser to have English at the top. For Chrome it can be accessed at chrome://settings/languages .

I actually also had this issue with the CEMC software back in high school too.

Question:
Bonus Quizzes:

As for the bonus quizzes, is it better for us to do them now or wait until we learn enough from the course?

These bonus quizzes are extensions of some of the material we do in class.  You will probably get more out of them if you wait until we have covered the related topics in class.

Bonus Quiz 2 talks about proofs by contradiction, so probably wait until we cover Chapter 3.

Bonus Quiz 3 is related to the material from Chapter 9 (RSA and computer security).

Bonus Quiz 4 is related to the material from Chapter 10 (complex numbers).

Question:

Question:
Do we need to justify our proofs of a set of numbers existing which meet a certain specification?:

For questions which ask to prove there exists a set of numbers that meet a certain specification, such as in WA1, Question 1b, do we need to justify our answer or can we just provide a set of numbers which meet the specification? Like for example in this question, providing 4 integers which prove P(4).

WA1 Question 1b for reference:

Let P(n) denote the open sentence

          n can be written as a sum of four perfect cubes.

Prove P(4), P(5) and P(−5)
Answer:
You don't need to explain how you came up with your solution - just demonstrate that it works. For example, to prove $$P(13)$$, your proof would include the line $$13=10^3+7^3+1^3+(-11)^3$$.

Check out p. 39 of the course notes about proving existentially quantified statements. Finding a solution by trial-and-error may seem like "magic", but it's still mathematically valid.

Question:
Question about Negation of a statement:

What is the negation of "This statement is TRUE?"

Since "The statement is FALSE" is a paradox and cannot be regarded as a statement, what should the negation of "This statement is TRUE" be, or it is simply not a statement?
Answer:
A very interesting question that was asked in my lecture this morning - I sent an email to my classlist, but I assume you are not in my section. Here's the email I sent:

"My takeaways are that (1) the word "This" in both sentences refer to different things, so they aren't actually negations of each other; and (2) the sentence is a "reverse paradox" in the sense that the reader can assign a truth value to "This statement is true.", and either choice is consistent, but no truth value is forced by the sentence itself."

To answer the question in the title, I think the negation would be something like "The negation of "This statement is true" is true". We don't change the domain when we negate statements, so "this" should refer to the same thing before and after negation (thanks to Peter for pointing this out!).

Question: What does it mean by “Do not use the notation P(n)” in WA1 Q1: Hi I was just wondering if anyone could explain what does it mean by not using the P(n) notation? Would it mean I can’t express the mathematical statement using such letters?
Answer:
What it means here is recall P(n): $$n$$ can be written as a sum of four perfect cubes.

So do not write the statement in symbols by writing, for example,  if the quantifier is a universally quantified statement and domain in S,  Then you have something like,

$$\forall n \in S, P(n)$$. Just expressing your open sentence as $$P(n)$$ is what you are told to avoid. Rather use the definition `` $$n$$ can be written as a sum of four perfect cubes'' and write that in symbols.

Question: Negation of a statement: To get the negation of ∃a ∈ Z, ∀b ∈ Z, 3a = b without using words or the ¬ symbol, would we just have to change that 3a≠b and keep the rest of the statement the same?
Answer: When you negate an existential quantifier, it becomes a universal quantifier and vice versa,  you then also have to negate the open sentence.  Changing $$3a=b$$ to $$3a \neq b$$ is negating the open sentence.  You need to do more.

Question:
Clarification about nested quantifier:

For the following nested quantifier, what would be the correct way to read/interpret it?

$$\exists x\epsilon \mathbb{Z}, \forall y\epsilon \mathbb{R}, x+y=0$$

Does this mean, "Is there an explicit value of x that will make the equation true for all values of y"? In other words, can we let x=-y to make the equation true or that wouldn't work in this situation?
Answer:
This wouldn't work because x is being chosen first,  and then you have to make sure x + y = 0 no matter what y you choose to go along with that x.

The student answer is great. Think of the quantified variables as being chosen by players in a game. In your example, $$x$$ is being chosen first, then $$y$$, because of the order of the quantifiers.

Now notice which quantifiers they are - existential first, then universal. Thus we would interpret this as “there exists an $$x$$ that works for all $$y$$”. Hopefully this helps you verify the truth or falsehood of the statement now.

Question:
Question on Open Sentences:

Hello! 

I had a question on open sentences. I know that an open sentences are expressions that can be dependent on n number of variables, and these variables are within P(x1,x2,x3..). However I was wondering can open sentences have can have several variables  but in P(x1,x2...) only few are actually stated. 

To be more precise, if i were to stay let P(X): x^2 = y, would that be considered an open sentence? Y is still a variable even if P(X) is defined or would it have to be P(x,y).

If it has to be P(x,y) would it be safe to assume that if P(x) is an open sentence that sentence only has one variable?    

Thank you
Answer:
It has to be $$P(x, y) \colon x^2 = y$$.

So you are correct: when one writes $$P(x)$$, this means that the open sentence $$P$$ depends on exactly one variable.

Here's an exercise for you. Let $$P(x, y)$$ be the open sentence $$x^2 = y$$. Determine if each of the following is

  • a true statement
  • a false statement
  • an open sentence that depends on x
  • an open sentence that depends on y
  • an open sentence that depends on both $$x$$ and $$y$$
  • neither an open sentence nor a statement

(a) $$P(x, y)$$

(b) $$P(x, 5)$$

(c) $$P(3, y)$$

(d) $$\exists x \in \mathbb R, P(x, y)$$

(e) $$\forall y \in \mathbb Q, P(x, y)$$

(f) $$\exists y \in \mathbb Z, P(-3, y)$$

(g) $$\forall x \in \mathbb Q, P(x, 4)$$

I believe that P(X): x^2 = y would not be an open sentence because there is no way to evaluate if it's true or false, given that the value of y is not given in the function.

Question:
Expressing statement in symbolic form: extra practice problems week 1, q 3.d:

I'm trying to figure out how to express the following in symbolic form: "There is a perfect square which is also a perfect cube".

This is what I have come up with:

$$\exists a \in A, \exists b \in B, a = b$$

$$\text{where } A \text{ is the set of all perfect squares and } B \text{ is the set of all perfect cubes}.$$

Is it fine to create my own domain (such as A and B in my solution above) or should this problem have been completed differently?

Thank you.
Answer: You can make your own domains as long as they're defined precisely. However, there is a clean way to do this problem using common set names.

Question:

Is there a difference between writing 

∃ x, y ∈ Z and ∃ x ∈ Z, ∃ y ∈ Z

If the domain is the same for one or more variables in a mathematical statement, could I always just use example one to express it?
Answer: Yes. But only when the quantifiers and domains are all the same.

Question:
How is this is a statement?:

How is the following question (from extra practice 1) a statement?

"The equation $$x^2+2x-3=0$$ has a real solution."

I thought for something to be a statement it must not have undefined variables.
Answer:
The graph of a quadratic equation either crosses/touches the x axis (has a solution) or doesn't (no solution).

If the equation was $$x^2+2x+m=0$$, for example, then the value of m would determine if it had a real solution or not, and that wouldn't be a statement.

Question:
Does EP1 question 3C require 3 quantifiers?:

For question 3, c in extra practice 1, is it necessary to use 3 quantifiers to express the statement in symbolic form?

The statement is, "Every natural number can be expressed as the product of two integers".

In symbolic form, I wrote the following as the answer: $$\forall x \epsilon \mathbb{N}, \exists y \epsilon \mathbb{Z}, \exists z \epsilon \mathbb{Z}, x=y+z$$

Assuming I have the right answer, is the only way to express this statement in symbolic form using three quantifiers?
Answer:
I think there may be a way to write this with things like conjunctions, but the price for using less quantifiers is a much longer statement (probably a compound statement). Your approach seems natural enough - although you may want to doublecheck your open sentence.

Question:
Question about 1.4.1, the use of the capital letter P:

__2023-09-09___5.52.32.png

I am confused about the last sentence. What does "x has property P" mean? And why does this issue have something to do with the capital letter?

Thank you
Answer:
This is best explained with the help of an example. 

$$\exists x \in \mathbb{R}, x^2 = 0$$
Here, $$P(x): x^2 = 0$$. Note that P(x) represents the fact that x has the "property" that squaring it yields zero. 
The 'P' comes from [P]roperty.
The letter $$P$$ is just a name. You can use any letter you want, like when you name a function.
The fact that it’s a capital letter isn’t really important, the writer is just describing in words which symbol they’re referring to.

Question:
EP1 1 (c):

The question states to determine whether or not the quantified statement is true or false.

1 (c) states: 

$$∀p ∈ Q, ∃q ∈ Z, |p − q| ≤ 1$$

Would this be a false statement because when q is a negative integer (as the sign of the integer is not mentioned) the inequality deems as false because the absolute value of p - q would end up being larger than 1.
Answer:
<md>It should be true? According to 1.5 Nested Quantifiers, the statement should be read from left to right, so it is, "For all rational numbers $$p$$, there exists an integer $$q$$ such that $$|p-q| \le 1$$. So basically you can randomly choose a rational number $$p$$, and you can always find an integer $$q$$ under this $$p$$ such that $$|p-q| \le 1$$, so it is true.</md>
Note that the second quantifier for the domain $$q \in \mathbb{Z}$$ is an existential quantifier. In class, you learned that the existential quantifier tells you that there exists (could be one or more) elements with a certain property that satisfies the proposition.

Question: Nested Quantified Statement: How do we determine is a nested quantified statement is true or false? I read the course notes, however, I am still confused.
Answer:
For nested quantifiers, the key point is to read from the left to the right and the order matters.

For example,
1. $$\forall x \, \in \mathbb{Z},\, \forall y \in \mathbb{Z}, \, x +y = 0  $$. 

What do you think is the true value of this statement? Well, that is a false statement.  What does the statement mean? It says for every integer x and every integer y,  the sum of x and y is always zero.  Is this true? (Recall the definition of your universal quantifiers) You can quickly give me some examples where the proposition fails.   So the statement is false!


How about 
2. $$\forall x \, \in \mathbb{Z},\, \exists y \in \mathbb{Z}, \, x +y = 0  $$.  This statement is true.

For every x,  there could be at least a y so that the proposition is true. I just have to choose y = -x. (Recall the definition for existential quantifier)

Now, think about the truth values for 

3. $$\exists x \, \in \mathbb{Z},\, \exists y \in \mathbb{Z}, \, x +y = 0  $$. 
4. $$\exists x \, \in \mathbb{Z},\, \forall y \in \mathbb{Z}, \, x +y = 0  $$. 

Remember to always read from left to right. The order is important. (In other words, statement 4 is not the same as statement 2).
Statement 4 reads for at least one choice of $$x \in \mathbb{Z}$$ Is it true that for all integer y, x+y =0?
For nested quantifiers, the key point is to read from the left to the right and the order matters.

For example,
1. $$\forall x \, \in \mathbb{Z},\, \forall y \in \mathbb{Z}, \, x +y = 0  $$. 

What do you think is the true value of this statement. Well, that is a false statement.  What does the statement mean? It says for every integer x and every integer y,  the sum of x and y is always zero.  Is this true? (Recall the definition of you universal quantifiers) You can quickly give me some examples where the proposition fails.   So the statement is false!


How about 
2. $$\forall x \, \in \mathbb{Z},\, \exists y \in \mathbb{Z}, \, x +y = 0  $$.  This statement is true.

For every x,  there could be at least a y so that the proposition is true. I just have to choose y = -x. (Recall the definition for existential quantifier)

Now, think about the truth values for 

3. $$\exists x \, \in \mathbb{Z},\, \exists y \in \mathbb{Z}, \, x +y = 0  $$. 
4. $$\exists x \, \in \mathbb{Z},\, \forall y \in \mathbb{Z}, \, x +y = 0  $$. 

Remember to always read from left to right. The order is important. (In other words, statement 4 is not the same as statement 2).
Statement 4 reads for at least one choice of $$x \in \mathbb{Z}$$ is it it true that for all integer y, x+y =0?

Question:
WA1 Q2a.:

I'm confused by the question as it says to let s(n) denote the sum of its positive divisors that are strictly less than n and when n = 1 it defines s(1) = 0 

given two examples: 

s(6) = 1+2+3=6

s(8) = 1+2+4=7

can someone pls explain the question and the example given
Answer:
Every non-zero integer $$n$$ has a finite number of positive divisors.

For example, the positive divisors of $$n = 2$$ are $$1$$ and $$2$$.

The positive divisors of $$n = 3$$ are $$1$$ and $$3$$.

The positive divisors of $$n = 4$$ are $$1$$, $$2$$ and $$4$$.

As an exercise, try determining the positive divisors of $$5$$, $$6$$, $$7$$, $$8$$ and $$9$$.

Now, the number $$s(n)$$ denote the sum of positive divisors of $$n$$ that are not equal to $$n$$.

So, looking at our examples above, $$s(2) = 1$$, $$s(3) = 1$$, and $$s(4) = 1 + 2 = 3$$.

Can you determine $$s(5)$$, $$s(6)$$, $$s(7)$$, $$s(8)$$ and $$s(9)$$?

Question: EP 1 Question 1.(C): Can someone explain to me why the answer is true?
Answer:
In english the statement states "for all rational numbers p, there is an integer z for $$|p-q|\leq 1$$

Because the domain for p is all rational numbers which are all integers and/or numbers that can be written as a fraction ex: $$8/4$$ and there is an integer q which makes the following open sentence less than or equal to 1. 

So if we took p as any rational number 36/6 and hence $$|(36/6) - q| \leq 1$$, we can then take an integer for q such as 6 itself to fit the open sentence.

Therefore giving us $$|(36/6) - 6|\leq 1 = |6 -6|\leq 1$$ and hence $$0\leq 1$$ which is true. Hope this helped.

Also an important thing is that you read from left to right whenever dealing with statements. This was mentioned in 1.5 of the Mobius textbook. 

In english the statement states "for all rational numbers p, there is an integer z for $$|p-q|\leq 1$$

Because the domain for p is all rational numbers which are all integers and/or numbers that can be written as a fraction ex: $$8/4$$ and there is an integer q which makes the following open sentence less than or equal to 1. 

So if we took p as any rational number 36/6 and hence $$|(36/6) - q| \leq 1$$, we can then take an integer for q such as 6 itself to fit the open sentence.

Therefore giving us $$|(36/6) - 6|\leq 1 = |6 -6|\leq 1$$ and hence $$0\leq 1$$ which is true. Hope this helped.

Question:
Question about Quantifiers:

The question on one of the mobius practice was:

If x is a real number, then e^x < 0

However, the feedback on the question stated:

Since e^x > 0 for all x, the truth value of the statement does not depend on x and so the statement is not conditional.

What does it mean by "the statement does not depend on x"?
Answer:
conditional = depends on something being true (in this case, “if x is real number”)

however

the feedback is saying the veracity of e^x > 0 does not depend on x being real or not

Edit: This is not quite right. The veracity of $$e^x > 0$$ does depend on x being a real number. Once we know $$x$$ is a real number, then $$e^x > 0$$ follows regardless of what value x takes. If x were not necessarily real, then it could be $$x = i\pi$$, in which case $$e^x = -1 < 0$$.

 
conditional = depends on something being true (in this case, “if x is real number”)

however

the feedback is saying the veracity of e^x > 0 does not depend on x being real or not

Edit: This is not quite right. The veracity of $$e^x > 0$$ does depend on x being a real number. Once we know $$x$$ is a real number, then $$e^x > 0$$ follows regardless of what value x takes. If x were not necessarily real, then it could be $$x = i \cdot pi$$, in which case $$e^x = -1 < 0$$.

 
conditional = depends on something being true (in this case, “if x is real number”)

however

the feedback is saying the veracity of e^x > 0 does not depend on x being real or not

 
Even though the value of $$x$$ was not defined (that is, we don't know if it should 1, 0.2, or $$\pi$$, for example), $$e^x$$ is positive for all $$x$$ real, which makes it not depend on the value of $$x$$.

Question:
Issue with the understanding of Open Sentence:

Hi, I am not sure whether my understanding of open sentences is correct or not.

Can I think the open sentence as a sentence that contains at least one variable that has not been assigned with a domain? But once that variable has been assigned with a specific domain (E.g. x belongs to real number / x = 5 / x>1 etc.), then it becomes a statement.

Thanks in advance for the answers!
Answer:
For example, x $$\leq$$ x + 1 - This is an open sentence since we don't know what x is.

In order for it to become a statement, you need to say $$\forall x \in\mathbb Z, x \leq x + 1$$

The only difference is that we define what x is (in this case, what set it belongs to)

For example, x $$\leq$$ x + 1 - This is an open sentence since we don't know what x is.

In order for it to become a statement, you need to say $$\forall x \in\mathbb Z, x \leq x + 1$$

For example, x $$\leq$$ x + 1 - This is n open sentence since we don't know what x is.

In order for it to become a statement, you need to say $$\forall x \in\mathbb Z, x \leq x + 1$$

For example, x $$\leq$$ x + 1 - This is a statement since we don't know what x is.

In order for it to become a statement, you need to say $$\forall x \in\mathbb Z, x \leq x + 1$$

If a  variable is unquantified, then you will have an open sentence.  If all the variables are quantified (which includes giving their domain), then it will be a statement.

Question:
Mobius Practice Problems:

Hello! One of the practice questions of mobius was this question right here. From my understanding this "translates" to there exists a integer Z, for all y integers such that x^2<= y^2. Answer:
The statement says that there is some integer x whose square is less than or equal to the square of any integer. 0 is such an integer.  Remember that you cannot choose a variable that is existentially quantified. The statement says that there is some integer x whose square is less than or equal to the square of any integer. 0 is such an integer. The statement says that there is some integer $$x$$ whose square is less than or equal to the square of any integer. 0 is such an integer.

If you chose x to be 0, every value of y satisfies the expression.

Question:

Question:
nested quantifier statement:

How can we interpret this question? a or b

a) We randomly pick one q value and find if all the s in real numbers fit the function.

b) We find a value q such as 2 to make the function work with any s in real numbers.

A further question comes after a

If it is a

What is the difference between using two universal quantifiers?

A further question comes after b

If it is b

What is the difference if we change the order of the quantifiers?
Answer:
There are some details about the language you used. $$\exists q$$ means that it is possible to find a $$q$$. This value is not random, for the statement to be true you would have to find at least one such $$q$$, so that is more like what you wrote on b. The difference if we change the order is that, for each value of $$s$$, we would have to find a value of $$q$$ instead, which is a different statement.

Remember that we read from left to right.

Question:
Extra Practice Chap 1 #3a):

I stumbled across this question while doing 3a) from extra practice.

Could an alternative negation of  $$\exists x \epsilon\mathbb{R},x^2+2x-3=0$$

be $$\forall x \epsilon\mathbb{R},x^2+2x-3=0$$ instead of $$\forall x \epsilon\mathbb{R},x^2+2x-3\not\equiv 0$$.  I was thinking, since for all x values, the equation won't be satisfied, this would already be false which fits the definition of a negation since the truth values are flipped.
Answer: The equation does have solutions, $$x=1$$ and $$x=-3$$. But, in case there weren't solutions, the negation would still be $$\forall x \in \mathbb{R}, x^2+2x-3\neq 0$$.

Question: Is 0 a perfect square/perfect cube?: Would 0 be considered a perfect square and/or a perfect cube for this course?
Answer: Can you write 0 as $$x^2$$ for some integer $$x$$?  If so, then 0 is a perfect square.  Similarly, can you write 0 as $$x^3$$ for some integer $$x$$?  If so, then 0 is a perfect cube.

Question:
Proving Quantified Statements:

I wanted to clarify how to proof quantified statements. For questions like: 

$$\forall x E\mathbb{R},\forall yE\mathbb{R},x^3-y^3=1$$ 

We can prove the statement is false through counter examples. 

But if we have a statment like this: 

$$\exists xE\mathbb{R},\forall yE\mathbb{R},x^3-y^3=1$$

How can we mathematically  prove that there is no real number x that for all of real number y, x^3 -y^3 =1 

Thanks!
Answer:
Two canonical methods:

1) Prove the negation to disprove the current statement.

2) Proof by contradiction which we'll discuss later. Essentially, you assume that such an x exists and show that this leads to a contradiction.

Question: Difference between quantifying versus fixing a variable: In class we learned that we can turn an open sentence into a statement by quantifying or fixing the variable(s). But what exactly is the difference between quantifying and fixing?
Answer: I would need to see how your professor introduced "fixing" a variable, but I would guess that quantifying a variable involves turning an open sentence like "x + 2 = 3" into a statement like "There is a natural number x such that x + 2 = 3," but fixing a variable means giving a particular value for the unspecified variable x. For example, when x = 1, the sentence becomes "1 + 2 = 3" which is now a true statement. In the latter case we have "fixed" a particular value of the variable.

Question: Quantifier for the term "arbitrary": While looking at Mobius there were a couple statements that used the term "arbitrary" to refer to a value (e.g. "an arbitrary real number x"). What quantifier matches the word "arbitrary" ? Is it sometimes existential and sometimes universal? Many of us are confused so we were wondering how we can tell.
Answer:
"Arbitrary" usually means "any," and translates symbolically to a statement involving the quantifier $$\forall$$. For example, the following statements mean the same thing: 

``For an arbitrary integer x, x < x+1"


``$$\forall x \in \mathbb{Z}$$, x < x+1" 

"Arbitrary" usually means "For any," and translates symbolically to a statement involving the quantifier $$\forall$$. For example, the following statements mean the same thing: 

``For an arbitrary integer x, x < x+1"


``$$\forall x \in \mathbb{Z}$$, x < x+1"

Question:
Order of quantifiers:

Hi, I'm a little confused about the order of quantifiers. I understand that we have to read a statement from left to right to determine the truth value, but for some statements when I try to convert it to symbolic form, I get confused as to which quantifier should come first.

Question: Basic question about sets: Can a set be named literally anything. Can I assign a $ sign to the name of a set?
Answer: Technically yes, but most often we use capital letters like $$X, Y, Z, \mathbb{R}$$ to denote sets.

Question:
WA1 Q5(b) question:

Can a quantified statement not include the domain for one of the variables of its open statement?

For example, is "for all integer values of x, x + y > 0" an open sentence or a statement?
Answer:
It's an open sentence because we don't know what sort of object $$y$$ is. A good way to think about this is that the open sentence could be true or false depending on how we quantify $$y$$, whereas for a proper statement, its truth value cannot be variable; it must be either true or false.
It's an open sentence because we don't know what sort of object $$y$$ is. A good way to think about this is that the open sentence could be true or false depending on how we quantify $$y$$, whereas for a proper statement, its truth value cannot switch; it must be either true or false.
It's an open sentence because we don't know what sort of object $$y$$ is.

Question:
Q1 (c) quantifier:

Does every domain has to have quantifiers?

For examples, when we turn the statement "every integer n can be written as a sum of two perfect squares" into the symbolic form,

does the following expression work?

$$\forall n \in \mathbb{Z}, a,b \in \mathbb{Z}, n=a^2+b^2$$

or should I have to include the quantifier as the following?

$$\forall n \in \mathbb{Z}, \exists a,b \in \mathbb{Z}, n=a^2+b^2$$
Answer: You should include the quantifiers. If you leave any variables unquantified, the result is not a statement at all but rather an open sentence.

Question:
Questions about lessons so far:

I have a few questions from the lessons we've had so far. 

1. How do we identify a the quantifier, domain, variable and open sentence in a statement (with words)?

     eg. "x^2 + 2x - 3 = 0 has a real solution" and "Every natural number can be expressed as the product of two integers"

2. With nested quantifiers, I know the order of the quantifiers matter but how so? Also, does a specific order usually mean the statement is true or false? 

     eg. if you have two quantifiers, and the first one is "for all" and the second one is "there is at least", doesn't this mean that the statement would probably be true (in most cases)?

3. In our notes, we wrote (in symbols) " For all x in the set s, p(x)". I'm confused as to how this is a statement when we haven't defined p(x) yet? Isn't p(x) it's own function?(eg. shouldn't this be an open statement?)

4. Is there a difference between a statement vs a quantified statement?

5. Does each quantifier (in nested quantifiers) have it owns/is associated with its own variables and domain?

6. When converting a statement into symbols, is there a comma or period mark at the end of the statement?
Answer:
1.  Write the equivalent symbolic statement, then it should be clear which each of the parts are.

2.  The order of the quantifiers will most likely affect the truth value of the statement.  The second part of your question here can't really be answered. It depends on the open sentence you are considering. 

3.  It's difficult to talk about the general form of statements.  But yes, you are correct that if we don't know what $$P(x)$$ is, then technically it's an open sentence because the sentence depends on the choice of $$P(x)$$.

4.  A quantified statement is one which has quantifiers as a part of it.  But not all statements have quantifiers.  For example, $$2=3$$ is a false statement that doesn't involve quantifiers.

5.  Each variable in a statement will have its own domain and its own quantifier.

6.  You don't need punctuation at the end of a symbolic statement. 

1. x^2 +2x-3=0 is the open sentence, as the variable is undefined

    the quantifier is ∃ because it says it has "a" meaning only one

    the domain is the real numbers as it mentions

    the variable is x

2. it depends on the statement 

3. no, this is a general statement, x is defined to be in the set of S, and p(x) is what p is at x

4. a quantified statement has a quantifier, domain, variable and open sentence

5. if a quantifier is needed, it can be added for how many ever variables you have

6. there's a comma after each variable has been assigned to a set

Question: A question about this example from class: In yesterday's class, an example question is as follows : $$\forall\alpha\in\emptyset$$ $$\alpha^2=3$$ is a true statement. According to my understanding in high school(may be wrong) $$\forall\alpha\in\emptyset$$ doesn't make sence logically, so no matter what open sentence is written behind it, it is a true statement. However, $$\exists\alpha\in\emptyset$$ does make sence, so the statement with it can be wrong. Is my opinion correct? If it's correct, then "$$\forall\alpha\in\emptyset$$ $$\alpha$$ is not an element of empty set" is also a true statement, right?
Answer:
$$\forall \alpha \in \emptyset , P(\alpha)$$ does make sense. The point is that $$\forall$$ does not guarantee existence. So the fact that you cannot explicitly choose a $$\alpha \in \emptyset$$ for which $$\alpha^2=3$$ does not make the statement false. 

$$\exists \alpha \in\emptyset$$ set also “makes sense”, but will lead to a false statement since there are no numbers in $$\emptyset$$. (You can read “$$\exists$$” as “there is a”)

Question: order of nested statements: is "some x value is greater than all y values" logically equivalent to "all y values are less than some x value"? I know for opposing quantifiers the order matters but this sounds right to me
Answer:
The two statements you wrote are the same, but they do not correspond to swapping the order of quantifiers. They are just different ways of saying the same statement in english

They both mean " $$\exists x\in S$$ such that  $$\forall y \in S$$, $$x>y$$"

Changing the order of quantifiers would be

$$\forall y\in S, \exists x\in S, x>y$$

The swapped statement means for every $$y$$, you can find a $$x$$ bigger than that given $$y$$, while the original statement means there is a $$x$$ which is bigger than all other $$y$$'s

The two statements you wrote are the same, but they do not correspond to swapping the order of quantifiers. They are just different ways of saying the same statement in english

They both mean " $$\exists x\in S$$ such that  $$\forall y \in S$$, $$x>y$$"

Changing the order of quantifiers would be

$$\forall y\in S, \exists x\in S, x>y$$

The second means for every $$y$$, you can find a $$x$$ bigger than that given $$y$$, while the first statement means there is a $$x$$ which is bigger than all other $$y$$'s

Not the same; order matters.

In the first statement, you are saying a single possible value of x in its set is greater than all possible values of y in its set.

In the second statement, you are saying all possible values of y in its set each have their own individual possible value of x its set that is less than y

Question:
Implication Practice: <md>I'm wondering about the following question after today's lesson

```
Find the truth value for this statement 

"For all x in the real number set, if x^2 > 0, then x > 0

```

So, we can deduce that the hypothesis is true (`x^2>0`), but I'm not sure is x > 0 is true</md>
Answer:
$$(-1)^2 > 0$$ but $$-1 < 0$$.

When you're trying to determine the truth value of an implication, you assume (it's important not to think of it as a 'deduction' here) the hypothesis and check if the conclusion holds.

A common source of confusion is thinking of an implication in terms of its conclusion alone. The conclusion is implicitly linked with the assumption you make, and a true implication only tells you that conclusion follows IF the assumption were true.
$$(-1)^2 > 1$$ but $$-1 < 0$$.

Question:
Ch 2.2 Textbook Example - Disjunction:

The Math 135 textbook has this example to help explain disjunction.

Reading this out loud makes sense to me. If $$x^3 \leq 0$$, otherwise $$x\geq 0$$. Yet by themself using the 'for all' quantifier, both are false. So if (false) or (false) = false.

So clearly I am misunderstanding something from the transition from English to the symbolic math. Please help.
Answer:
You are mistaking this statement with $$(\forall x\in \mathbb R, x^3\leq 0)\lor (\forall x \in \mathbb R, x\geq 0)$$, which is false
You are mistaking this statement with $$(\forall x^3\in \mathbb R, x\leq 0)\lor (\forall x \in \mathbb R, x\geq 0)$$, which is false
You are mistaking this statement with $$(\forall x \in \mathbb R, x\geq 0)\lor (\forall x\in \mathbb R, x\leq 0)$$, which is false
You are mistaking this statement with $$(\forall x \in \mathbb R, x\geq 0)\lor (\forall x\in \mathbb R, x\leq 0)$$, which is false
You are mistaking this statement with $$(\forall x \in \mathbb R, x\geq 0)\lor (\forall x\in \mathbb R, x\leq 0)$$

Answer:
all variables need to be quantified to qualify as a statement
A statement needs to have a definite truth value. A sentence like yours could become a true or a false statement depending on how you quantify $$y$$, so there's ambiguity.

Question: Are mathematical statements the same as quantified statements?: If an expression has no quantifiers or not ones for every variable, can it still be considered a mathematical statement just not a quantified statement?
Answer:
A statement need not have any variables, in which case quantifiers don't come into the picture. Some examples are as follows:

1. $$3 > 2$$
2. $$3^2 = 9$$
3. $$(3, 4, 5)$$ is a Pythagorean triplet.

Note that all three of these are true statements but I could've just as easily created a false statement without using variables.
A statement need not have any variables, in which case quantifiers don't come into the picture. Some examples are as follows:

1. $$3 > 2$$
2. $$3^2 = 9$$
3. $$(3, 4, 5)$$ is a Pythagorean triplet.

Question: Proving by using examples: In class, we were taught that proving by using examples is an invalid way of proving a statement. However, when it comes to existential variables, I find it easier to just give plug in numbers and show that the existential statement holds. So I guess my question is that when we have a statement with quantifiers that are solely existential, is it an acceptable practice to use examples? Will marks be deducted if I do so?
Answer:
examples is not a valid way of proving universally quantified statements. Examples are fine for existentially quantified statements 

(the exception for universally quantified statements is if there are finite elements in your set, then you can prove the statement with finintely many examples)

Question:
EP2 Q3 b):

Hi, I'm wondering if the following statements are logically equivalent:

 $$\forall m \in \mathbb{Z}, \exists a \in \mathbb{Z}, a = 2m, \exists b \in \mathbb{Z}, b = a + 1, \exists c \in \mathbb{Q}, a < c < b \wedge b < c < a$$

and

For every integer a and odd integer b, a rational number c can always be found such that a < c < b or b < c < a.

Thanks.
Answer:
I suspect the original statement has "even" integer $$a$$. Your formulation is not correct because it imposes the condition that $$a$$ and $$b$$ are consecutive integers which is not part of the original statement.

Instead of using additional variables to express parity, it's better use more specialized domains for $$a$$ and $$b$$. Let $$\mathbb{Z}_O$$ and $$\mathbb{Z}_E$$ be the set of odd and even integers respectively. Can you use these to formulate the statement?

Question:
Writing in Symbolic Form:

Hi,

Are there specific keywords in statements that can help us determine whether it is an implication or an "if and only if" statement?

Example: Would the following statement be an implication?

For every even integer a and odd integer b, a rational number c can always be found such that
a < c < b or b < c < a.
Answer:
There are two (natural) ways of formulating this. You can skip the implication altogether by using specialized domains for $$a$$ and $$b$$. Another approach is to use the parities of $$a$$ and $$b$$ as the hypotheses of an implication. Trying to formulate the statement in both ways is a good exercise.

Look for words such as 'equivalent', 'necessary and sufficient', etc. to spot an iff statement. 

For implications such as $$A \implies B$$, we may write that A is a sufficient condition for B or that B is a necessary condition for A.
There are two (natural) ways of formulating this. You can skip the implication altogether by using specialized domains for $$a$$ and $$b$$. Another approach is to use the parities of $$a$$ and $$b$$ as the hypotheses of an implication. Trying to formulate the statement in both ways is a good exercise.

Question: Question on Implication Tables: Must all four conditions of an implication table be met for an implication to be true? Or are there only certain ones that are considered?
Answer:
For the implication, the first thing you notice from the truth table is, 
For example, let A and B be statements. If statement A and statement B have the same truth values then the statement is always true. 

Also, If the hypothesis is False, then no matter what the conclusion is the statement is always True. 

You only get a false statement when the hypothesis is true and the conclusion is False.
For the implication, the first thing you notice from the truth table is, 
For example, let A and B be statements. If the statement A and B have the same truth values then the statement is always true. 

Also, If the hypothesis is False, then no matter what the conclusion is the statement is always True. 

You only get a false statement when the hypothesis is true and the conclusion is False.
For the implication, the first thing you notice from the truth table is, 
For example, let A and B be statements. If they have the same truth values then the statement is always true. 

Also, If the hypothesis is False, then no matter what the conclusion is the statement is always True. 

You only get a false statement when the hypothesis is true and the conclusion is False.

Question:
EP2 Q9: Are quantifiers included reversed in converses and contrapositives?:

I'm looking at EP2 Q9, which says "For all $$x\in\mathbb{R}$$, if $$x^6 + 3x^4 − 3x < 0,$$ then $$0 < x < 1$$. When finding the contrapositives, do I have to invert the quantifiers when calculating the negations? Like the quantifier "For all $$x\in\mathbb{R}$$?

Or do I simply invert what's after "if?" Currently what I have for the contrapositive is "For all $$x\in\mathbb{R}$$, if $$\leq 0\vee x\geq 1$$, then $$x^6 + 3x^4 - 3x \geq 0$$

Thanks!
Answer: The words contrapositive and converse apply to an implication and so you don't change the quantifiers that are applied to the entire implication.  However, if there are quantifiers within either the hypothesis or the conclusion, then they will be affected when you take the contrapositive.

Question:
Extra Practice:

How would you go about solving this problem?
Answer:
This statement cannot be proved because it's false. $$a = 9, b = 6, c = 3$$ and $$a = 4, b = 6, c = 6$$ are a couple of counter-examples. This statement cannot be proved because it's false. $$a = 9, b = 6, c = 3$$, $$a = 4, b = 6, c = 6$$ are a couple of counter-examples. What have you tried so far?

If you really want to know, then you should prove by cases:

If a | bc then we need to consider 2 cases. For c and b.

Case 1:

Let b be equal to (ma) for some integer m.

Therefore bc = (ma)c = a(mc). This is divisible by a. 

 

Case 2:

Let c be equal to (ma) for some integer m

bc = b(ma) = a(mb). This is divisible by a. 

 

Edit: a has to be less than b or c for this to work. You can't use it here. My mistake 

It would work if the statement was a converse. 

 

:-)

 

Instructor edit: Letting $$b = ma$$ for some integer m is equivalent to assuming that $$a$$ divides $$b$$ which is what you're trying to prove.

Case 1:

Let b be equal to (ma) for some integer m.

Question:
Trouble understanding how the placement of quantified variables affect question meaning:

I am having difficulty understanding the differences between how the quantified variables in question 1 and 2 affect each part of the implication and/or mathematical statement. What is the affect of placing the statement “for all integers x and y” at different parts of the question on the meaning? Can someone please explain it?
Answer:
Putting the universal quantifier in the hypothesis means that it will be much more difficult to make the hypothesis true.   In the first version, for the hypothesis to be true you need $$a \mid(bx+cy)$$ no matter what integer values $$x$$ and $$y$$ are.  So $$a, b, c$$ have to work for all possible choices of $$x$$ and $$y$$.  So for example if $$a=2$$ and $$b=c=3$$, the hypothesis will be false because one possibility for $$x$$ and $$y$$ could be $$x =1$$ and $$y=2$$ which gives $$2 \mid 9$$ which is false. 

In the second version the hypothesis is true when $$a \mid(bx+cy)$$.  For example if $$a=2$$ and $$b=c=3$$ and $$x=y=2$$ we get $$2 \mid 12$$ which is true. 

Does that help?

Question:
Question about negation:

what is the negation of "if and only if?"
Answer:
Hi!

I would approach it this way:

$$\neg (A \iff B) \equiv \neg((A \implies B)\land(B\implies A)) $$

Then, it should be

$$(A \land \neg B) \lor (B \land \neg A)$$

Question:
Difference between Counter Example and Contradiction:

I am confused about counter example and contradiction. It seems that they are two different methods: Finding counter example means to find a specific example to disprove some statement, whereas contradiction is to assume the negation of a statement and then find contradiction. 

But when I look at the following question:

To me the method being used could either be contradiction or counter example. As the textbook mentioned, it is finding certain value, thus the method is counter example. But if I assume the statement is correct, then it should apply to all values a,b,c,x,y. But then assigning certain value to a,b,c,x,y, I find the implication fails. Isn't that a contradiction?

And for this question (it is from MATH137, but I am just confused about the method being used): 

It is contradiction since I am assuming the statement is true and get 1 < 1/2. But during that process, I have assigned epsilon with the value 1/2 to break the assumption. Isn't that a counter example?

Thanks for the answer in advance!
Answer:
Proof by contradiction is a method to prove that a statement is true. 

We assume that the negation of the statement we are trying to prove is true and then we show that this assumption leads to a contradiction.  Therefore, the negation can't be true (ie it's false) and so the original statement is true. 

Giving a counterexample is a method to show that a universally quantified statement is false.

Question:
Quantifiers and Implication:

How can we determine if a statement requires quantifiers within the hypothesis?  What's the difference between a quantifier at the beginning vs when it is nested in the hypothesis? 

Thanks!
Answer:
consider a statement like this:

$$\forall x\in S,$$  (for all $$y\in S,$$ $$P(x,y))\implies Q(x)$$.

When you prove it, you are allowed to assume the hypothesis is true. This means that for given $$x\in S$$ you are allowed to assume $$P(x,y)$$ is true for any $$y\in S$$. This allows you to choose specific convinient values of $$y$$

On the other hand, if the statement were

$$\forall x,y\in S,$$ $$P(x,y)\implies Q(x)$$, then you could not choose a specific value of $$y$$. 

When you are proving universally quantified statements you should not choose specific values of the variable. But if you are assuming a universally quantified statement is true already, you are allowed to plug in whatever values you want

consider a statement like this:

$$\forall x\in S,$$  (for all $$y\in S,$$ $$P(x,y))\implies Q(x)$$.

When you prove it, you are allowed to assume the hypothesis is true. This means that for given $$x\in S$$ you are allowed to assume $$P(x,y)$$ is true for any $$y\in S$$. This allows you to choose specific convinient values of $$y$$

On the other hand, if the statement were

$$\forall x,y\in S,$$ if $$P(x,y)$$ implies $$Q(x)$$, then you could not choose a specific value of $$y$$. 

When you are proving universally quantified statements you should not choose specific values of the variable. But if you are assuming a universally quantified statement is true already, you are allowed to plug in whatever values you want

consider a statement like this:

$$\forall x\in S,$$ if for all $$y\in S$$ $$P(x,y)$$ implies $$Q(x)$$.

When you prove it, you are allowed to assume the hypothesis is true. This means that for given $$x\in S$$ you are allowed to assume $$P(x,y)$$ is true for any $$y\in S$$. This allows you to choose specific convinient values of $$y$$

On the other hand, if the statement were

$$\forall x,y\in S,$$ if $$P(x,y)$$ implies $$Q(x)$$, then you could not choose a specific value of $$y$$. 

When you are proving universally quantified statements you should not choose specific values of the variable. But if you are assuming a universally quantified statement is true already, you are allowed to plug in whatever values you want

@252

Question:
EP3 Q32 - Is this proof valid?:

Question: Disproving implications: Do we disprove an implication by directly giving a counter-example?
Answer:
yes you can use a counter example to try and disprove any universally quantified statement - this is the instructor's answer

Check out the truth table for a general implication $$A\Rightarrow B$$. It’s only false if $$A$$ is true but $$B$$ is false.

So the general strategy to disprove an implication is to assume the hypothesis and disprove the conclusion, e.g. by proving the negation of the conclusion.

If the conclusion you’re trying to disprove is a universal statement, then sure, you can use a counterexample.

Check out the truth table for a general implication $$A\Rightarrow B$$. It’s only false if $$A$$ is true but $$B$$ is false.

So the general strategy to disprove an implication is to assume the hypothesis and disprove the conclusion, e.g. by proving the negation of the conclusion.

Question: which step is incorrect while disproving universally quantified statement: Hi, if someone gives examples while disproving a universally quantified statement, I think the step of stating example is incorrect. But the mobius link question said it is correct until it get to the wrong result of the example.
Answer: To disprove a universally  quantified statement you give an example called a counter-example which shows the open sentence is false.  We take this approach because the negation of $$\forall x \in S,  P(x)$$ is $$\exists x \in S, \neg P(x)$$.

Question:
Converse of DIC:

Hi I was confused on the proof of the converse of DIC.  

I am confused how just the two cases x=1 y=0 and x=0, y=1 prove that a|b and a|c when a|(bx+cy) for every integer x and y. Shouldn't we consider other cases as well?
Answer:
In the converse of DIC we have universal quantification within the hypothesis.  So we assume that $$a \mid (bx+cy)$$ no matter what integers $$x$$ and $$y$$ we pick.  This is a really strong assumption.  If it's true for any $$x$$ and $$y$$, then it is definitely true when $$x=1$$ and $$y=0$$ as well as when $$x=0$$ and $$y=1$$.

The key thing in this proof is that we are assuming it is true in general and so it must be true in the specific.  (Note that we can't go the other way.  That is, we can't assume something is specifically true and then declare that it is true in general.)

Question:
Questions about Lecture:

1. Is proof by contradiction different than proving the negation? If so, how? I understand proofing the negation and how to negate the statement but I'm confused as what I do to the statement if its a proof by contradiction?
Answer:
<md> In classical logic (the one we're concerned with), they're equivalent. There's another type of logic called constructive or intuitionistic logic in which proofs by contradiction are invalid.


[Here's](https://math.andrej.com/2010/03/29/proof-of-negation-and-proof-by-contradiction/) a great article highlighting the differences between the two. </md>

Question:
Wording of a statement and its negation:

Hi,

 

I got this question (see screenshot) on the mobius assignment and I'm not sure I understand the explanation for why the solution is correct. I thought that in the original statement, "n is greater than 4" is a part of the domain, but in the solution statement it appears after "such as", doesn't that imply it's an 'and' statement? $$\forall n \in \mathbb{Z}_E, (n > 4) \implies (\text{there exist prime numbers p and q such that n = p + q})$$.

The solution is the negation of this formulation.
The original statement can be formulated as an implication:

$$\forall \in \mathbb{Z}_E, (n > 4) \implies (\text{there exist prime numbers p and q such that n = p + q})$$.

The solution is the negation of this formulation.
The original statement can be formulated as an implication:

Question: Does zero divide zero?: In terms of divisibility, zero can't divide anything that isn't zero for sure, as that would be undefined. But is zero defined as being able to divide itself? ie. does 0/0=1?
Answer:
0/0 is undefined.
In other words, zero cannot divide itself.
0/0 is undefined. $$\frac{x}{0}$$ is undefined for all real values $$x$$.  However, this is different than considering $$x \mid 0$$ or $$0 \mid x$$.  ("divides" is different than "divided by.")  $$x\mid 0$$ is true for any integer $$x$$ because we can always write $$0=0x$$.  $$0 \mid x$$ is only true for $$x=0$$ because we can't write $$x$$ as some integer times $$0$$ unless $$x=0$$.

Question: Office hour: Hi! I just wanna know what office hours do. I haven't attended once so I want to know how it works. Am I allowed to discuss assignment questions with the Professor? Can someone please give me some examples of what kind of questions I can ask during office hours? Thank you so much.
Answer:
You can ask about homework questions during office hours (AKA student hours). We won't give you answers, but we might give hints, similar to private Piazza posts that many students have made.

The most important thing is to have already tried something - don't come to student hours as a first resort. In math it is valuable, and often necessary, to sit with a problem before you can come up with a clever idea to solve it.

Of course, you don't have to ask about assignment problems. You can ask about lecture content, administrative details, etc.

Examples of good questions to ask:

"I tried proving this problem by contrapositive, but I got stuck. Here's my work so far. Do you have any hints?"

"Why do we define divisibility that way? Isn't it backwards?"

"Can you explain the proof of the converse of DIC again? I got lost at this step."

Hope that helps!

Question:

Question: Proof by Contradiction for general statements (not implications): Let's say we have a statement $$\forall x \in\mathbb{Z}, \forall y \in\mathbb{Z}, \exists z \in\mathbb{Z}, P(x,y,z))$$, if we want to proof by contradiction, do we negate the whole statement? So the statement we are assuming is true is $$\exists x \in\mathbb{Z},\exists y \in\mathbb{Z},\forall z \in\mathbb{Z}, \neg P(x,y,z)$$
Answer:
Proof by contradiction involves assuming the negation of a statement is true and based on that assumption reaching an impossible outcome, there by contradiction your original assumption. In doing so, you disprove the negation, thereby proving the original  statement.

And the negation you have written in your question is correct.

Proof by contradiction involves assuming the negation of a statement is true and based on that assumption reaching an impossible outcome, there by contradiction your original assumption. In doing so, you disprove the negation, thereby proving the original  statement. You need to take the negation of the statement (meaning all of the statement.)

Question:
Proving Subsets:

We have this proof method:

However, wouldn’t it be more concise to prove the following statement?

For all x \in S, x \in T. 
I think the statements should be equivalent. Is there any reason we want to define a U in this case?
Answer:
This is a great question! These statements are equivalent but here are some reasons we usually want to specify the universe of discourse:

1. U might specify what kind of object x is whereas S and T confer properties on x. For example, consider the statement $$\forall x \in \mathbb{N}, x \in \mathcal{P_2} \implies x \in \mathbb{Z_{odd}}$$ where $$\mathcal{P_2}$$ is the set of prime numbers $$> 2$$. Here, I could reformulate the statement without alluding to natural numbers but it's much clearer to specify the universe of discourse and reason about the properties separately.

2. Formulating the relation in terms of an implication makes it clear which proof strategy one should employ.

Let $$x$$ be a real number. Find the coefficient of $$x^{19}$$ in the expansion of $$(2x^3-3x)^9$$.

Question: WA4 Q1 (a): For Q1 (a), isn't the formula false when n = 0, because the question stated prove the formula for the sum of the first n "non-negative integers," which includes 0 but in the formula it states that $$\forall n \in \mathbb{N}$$ , which does not include 0?
Answer:
We are proving the formula for the sum of the first $$n$$ non-negative integers where $$n$$ is a natural number.  But the numbers that we are adding up are non-negative. 

So when $$n=2$$, for example, we are adding up the first 2 non-negative numbers which would be 0 and 1.

Question:
Can someone please explain this:

Hi, I am confused about the step where they start with (k+1)^2. It's very hard to read since everything is on one line. But where are they using the inductive hypothesis (k^2 > 2k+1) and using that to show P(k+1)? I can see that they are expanding (k+1)^2  but how are they showing that it is greater than 2(k+1)+1 using the inductive hypothesis? Sorry, it's just very hard to follow their example with everything on one line. I'd appreciate it if you can explain each step.

I really appreciate any help you can provide.
Answer:
$$(k+1)^{2} = k^{2}+2k+1$$

And we know this is larger than $$(2k+1)+(2k+1)$$ since $$k \geq 3$$

And we know that $$(2k+1) \geq 7$$, since again $$k \geq 3$$

So we can replace one $$(2k+1)$$ with 7 and state:

$$(2k+1)+(2k+1)\geq (2k+1)+7$$

Next we know:

$$(2k+1)+7=2k+8\geq 2k+3$$

And finally:

$$2k+3=2(k+1)+1$$

Therefore:

$$(k+1)^{2} > 2(k+1)+1$$

The student answer is correct. Just some remarks:

1. For $$k^2 + 2k + 1 > (2k+1) + 2k + 1$$, cite the inductive hypothesis.

2. It's better to write $$2(k+1) + 7 > 2k + 3$$ than $$2(k+1) + 7 \geq 2k + 3$$. It makes the conclusion clearer.
The student answer is correct. Just some remarks:

1. For $$k^2 + 2k + 1 \geq (2k+1) + 2k + 1$$, cite the inductive hypothesis.

2. It's better to write $$2(k+1) + 7 > 2k + 3$$ than $$2(k+1) + 7 \geq 2k + 3$$. It makes the conclusion clearer.
The student answer is correct. Just some remarks:

1. For $$k^2 + 2k + 1 \leq (2k+1) + 2k + 1$$, cite the inductive hypothesis.

Question:
EP4 Q9 - is this proof correct?:

For the tower of hanoi puzzle, working out the first few cases i guessed that a formula for the least amount of moves for a tower of n pegs is 2^n - 1. Is this way of proving it inductively correct?

Base case of 2 since it can be done in 3 moves but not in two

Assume least moves for a pillar of k height 

For a pillar with k+1 height, before the largest peg at the bottom of the tower can be moved, the pillar of height k ontop of it needs to be all moved onto another single peg, which takes 2^k - 1 moves by our inductive hypothesis. Now we can take 1 move to move the biggest block to the other remaining peg, and now we want to move the tower of k height onto the biggest peg. Since the peg is the biggest peg, it will not block anything we try to put on it. The minimum moves to move the tower of k onto another peg is again k^2 - 1 by our hypothesis, so the total amount of moves for a height of k+1 = 2^k + 2^k + 1 - 1 - 1 = 2^(k+1) - 1
Answer: You have a little typo where you write k^2-1 when you meant 2^k-1 but I think this looks good.

Question: POSI vs POMI: Is there any tip for choosing which one to use when doing induction proving?
Answer:
It all depends on your proof of the inductive conclusion, $$P(k+1)$$.  What do you need to be true to prove it?  If you only need $$P(k)$$ to be true to prove it, then POMI will suffice.  If you need $$P(i)$$ to be true for some value of $$i$$ which is less than $$k$$, then you will need to use POSI. 

In other words, if one step is true implies that the next step is true, POMI will suffice.  But if you need some previous step which is further back to be true, to prove the next step, then you will need POSI.

Answer:
On the Learn course, if you go under Assessments $$\to$$ Written Assignments (WA) — Crowdmark, the page has the late policy.

 

Note that although Crowdmark doesn't enforce strict deadlines, you must submit your assignment by the deadline listed in the Course Schedule. Crowdmark is set up to accept late submissions with a penalty at a rate of 1% per minute FOR THE ENTIRE ASSIGNMENT starting immediately after the deadline. For example, if you submit your assignment 60 minutes late and get a perfect score, you will earn 40%.

Please be aware that although you can make as many submissions as you wish before the deadline, Crowdmark will only accept one submission after it has passed (and this is only if you have not submitted anything at all before the deadline). If you do have to submit an assignment late, you must make sure that your submission is complete: upload all of your files and then click the "submit" button.

Question:
Nested Quantifier Statement:
I just wonder why the first is true while the second is false here, since the negation of the second will be true.
Answer:
The first one says that there's no largest real number, or equivalently, that you can always find a larger number no matter which real number you pick. We know this is true.

The second one says that there's a smallest real number. But, we know that we can always find a smaller number no matter which real number we pick, so it's false.

Question: Question about 5.4: In section 5.4, I don’t understand a step in the proof of proposition 1. Why B has at least as many sets in it as A and why A also has at least as many sets in it as B?
Answer:
Suppose A has $$n$$ sets. By definition, none of these contain $$k+1$$. Now, we add $$k+1$$ to all of these sets to obtain $$n$$ sets which all must be in B by definition. This shows us that there are at least as many elements in B as in A.

The second argument is similar.
Suppose A has $$n$$ sets. By definition, none of these contain $$k+1$$. Now, we add $$k+1$$ to all of these sets to obtain $$n$$ sets which all must be in B by definition, which shows us that there are at least element in B as in A.

The second argument is similar.
Suppose A has $$n$$ sets. By definition, none of these contain $$k+1$$. Now, we add $$k+1$$ to all of these sets to obtain $$n$$ sets which all must be in B by definition, which shows us that there are at least element in B as in A. Suppose A has $$n$$ sets. Question:
Confused about the textbook's example for nested quantifiers (pg.14):

I was reviewing the content for nested quantifiers, and in general, I understand why the order of quantifiers matter. However, there is one example in the textbook where I don't quite understand why the order of quantifiers matter.

I understand why the following statement is true:

∀ s ε ℝ, ∃ t ε ℝ, t > s

However, I don't understand why this statement (with the quantifiers in different order) is false:

∃ t ε ℝ, ∀ s ε ℝ t > s

Regarding the second statement, in theory, can't we just select the largest possible t in the set of real numbers, so that there is no s that is greater than or equal to t? I'm just quite confused as to why the first statement is true and the second is false. Would really appreciate some clarification. Thanks.
Answer:
There's no largest real number. We say that the real numbers are not bounded above to express this.

@632
For me, converting a mathematical statement to english sentence really helps as it gives me a more intuitive sense of what the sentence is saying. For the second statement, I read it like "There exists a real number, t, such that I can take any other real number, s, and it is guaranteed that s will always be less than t". Now with our prior knowledge of real numbers, we know that there is no upper bound to real numbers since there are infinitely many of them. And so since I can always find a larger real number, the statement must be false. Hope this helps!

Question: EP4 Q2f: I’m feeling stuck on how to approach this question. I can’t figure out a way to get 4^k - 1 from the inductive step
Answer:
Assume there exists k>=1 such that 3 | 4^k-1, then there must exist m such that 3m = 4^k-1.

4^(k+1)-1= 4^k*4-1= 4(3m+1) -1 = 12m+3 =3(4m+1) which is divisible by 3.

So 4^(k+1)-1 is divisible by 3 if 4^k-1 is divisible by 3.
I don't know whether this is true, but this is my solution

Question:
Question From Test Practice in Lecture:

Hi,

For question 5 from the Practice Questions given in lecture for Test 1, I was wondering if there was a better way to prove the question than what I came up with.

How I thought of solving this question was to disprove the negation, to show how the original statement is true. And then I used the contradiction on the negation of the statement that assume there does exist p and q (integers) s.t. p^2-q^2 = 10. Here, I noticed that it was a diff of squares so I split it into (p+q)(p-q) = 10. Then I have the potential test cases (since it can be positive or negative, 1 and 10, or 2 and 5 as well as other way around). And then after solving for the cases, I keep getting that q is not an integer and then I use that as a contradiction to show the negation must be false and the original statement is true. 

As you can tell, this is pretty long and exhaustive, so I was wondering if there was nice, shorter way to prove this.

Question:
EP3 Q8:

Hello,

I am completely stuck on question 8 from EP3:

Prove that for all $$r\in\mathbb{R}$$ where $$r\neq -1$$ and $$r\neq -2$$,

$$\dfrac{2^{r+1}}{r+2}-\dfrac{2^{r}}{r+1}=\dfrac{r(2^r)}{(r+1)(r+2)}$$

I tried getting a common denominator on the left side and expanding out the problem but I have nothing concrete. I understand that this may have something to do with the restrictions in the denominator but I have no idea how to prove anything here. Could anyone please help out?

Thank you
Answer:
Expanding the LHS gives

$$\dfrac{2^{r+1}}{r+2}-\dfrac{2^r}{r+1}=\dfrac{2^{r+1}(r+1)-2^r(r+2)}{(r+1)(r+2)}=\dfrac{r2^{r+1}+2^{r+1}-r2^r-2^{r+1}}{(r+1)(r+2)}=\dfrac{r(2^{r+1}-2^r)}{(r+1)(r+2)}.$$

Now we just need to show that $$2^r=2^{r+1}-2^r$$. Is this where you got stuck before?

Question: Proving an implication where there is an existentially quantified statement: For example if we have a proposition like "There exists a real number x such that , if x>0 then x^2 >0", we would just go about this similar to an implication with a universal quantifier right? First, assume x>0 and then show that x^2>0?
Answer:
In proving an existentially quantified statement, you would only need to find a single example, instead of showing that the implication is true for all real numbers x.

For example, if I were to say "there exists an integer x so that if x>0 then x<5", the value of x=4 would work for this.

But if the statement was "for all integers x, if x>0 then x<5", this is obviously not true anymore.

To add to the student answer, you can think of $$A \implies B$$ in terms of $$\neg A \lor B$$ if that makes it intuitively clearer.

Question: Divisibility notation: If we have something like ac|akc are we allowed to "cancel" the ac to get 1|k and have that be a part of our proof? Or is there a more rigorous way of proving this?
Answer:
1 divides everything so you can just state that $$1 \mid k$$ without any more justification. 

If you want to go from  $$am \mid mc$$ to  $$ a \mid c$$ (where $$ m\neq 0$$) you can just use the definition of divisibility.  That is, you can include this  proof: $$am \mid mc$$ implies that $$mc = amk$$. Therefore, dividing by $$m \neq 0$$ gives $$c=ak$$ which implies that $$ a \mid c$$.

Question:
Nested Quantifiers:

I am very lost on nested quantifiers. I was trying to review proofs from our lessons, and I'm still confused. In class, we did an example where we had to prove or disprove the following two statements:

  1. For all x, there exists some y such that x^3 -y^3 =1
  2. For all y, there exists some x such that x^3 -y^3 =1

We came to the conclusion that the first statement is true, and the second is false. For the second, we said "consider when y=x" and disproved it. But how isn't this a contradiction for the first statement as well? The first statement is claiming every single x value should work for some y, but every x won't work when x=y. I know my biggest confusion is that I'm not understanding what the order of the quantifiers actually mean. Could you explain the statements above and the what the order means?
Answer:
in the first one, "for all x, there exists y" means that no matter what $$x$$ you choose (presumably $$x\in \mathbb R$$), you can choose a $$y$$ which makes the statement $$x^3-y^3=1$$ true. Explicitly, no matter what $$x$$ one chooses, the value $$y= (-1+x^3)^{1/3}$$ works.  the order is important because $$y$$ depends on the choice of $$x$$. This is not the same as every single value of x should work for some y (that would be $$\exists y\in \mathbb R ,\forall x\in \mathbb R\dots$$)

For the second, $$x=y$$ is not a counter example. The second statement is true as well as far as i can tell, for the same reason as statement 1. I wonder if there is a typo?

in the first one, "for all x, there exists y" means that no matter what $$x$$ you choose (presumably $$x\in \mathbb R$$), you can choose a $$y$$ which makes the statement $$x^3-y^3=1$$ true. Explicitly, no matter what $$x$$ one chooses, the value $$y= (1-x^3)^{1/3}$$ works.  the order is important because $$y$$ depends on the choice of $$x$$. This is not the same as every single value of x should work for some y (that would be $$\exists y\in \mathbb R ,\forall x\in \mathbb R\dots$$)

For the second, $$x=y$$ is not a counter example. The second statement is true as well as far as i can tell, for the same reason as statement 1. I wonder if there is a typo?

Question:
Extra Practice 5: Q9, proving uniqueness:

I have attached the question below.

Could someone please let me know if my proof is valid:

Proof:

Existence:

Let $$T = \emptyset$$. Thus, for every set $$S$$, $$S \cup \emptyset = S$$.

Uniqueness:

Suppose there exists $$T_1$$ such that for every set $$S$$, $$S \cup T_1 = S$$. Let $$x \in (S \cup T_1)$$. Then, 

$$x \in (S \cup T_1) \equiv (x \in S) \lor (x \in T_1)$$

Thus, $$x \in S$$ or $$x \in T_1$$. If we want $$S \cup T_1 = S$$, then $$x \not\in T_1$$ or $$T_1 = S$$. However, $$S$$ can be any set, so $$T_1$$ cannot be defined in terms of $$S$$. Thus, we need to find $$T_1$$ such that for all sets $$S$$ and any $$x \in (S \cup T_1)$$, $$x \not\in T_1$$. Thus, $$T_1 = \emptyset$$.
Answer:
Your reasoning for uniqueness is unclear. The standard way to show uniqueness is to assume that two such sets exist and then show that they must be equal.

The phrase "$$T_1$$ cannot be defined in terms of $$S$$" is a bit weird. I'm not sure what that means. $$\emptyset = S\cap \overline S$$ is a way to define the empty set in terms of an arbitrary set for example.

when you say "If we want $$S \cup T_1 = S$$, then $$x \not\in T_1$$ or $$T_1 = S$$" I don't think that's true. $$T_1$$ could be any subset of $$S$$ and you might have $$x\in T_1$$ and $$T_1\neq S$$

Your reasoning for uniqueness is unclear. The standard way to show uniqueness is to assume that two such sets exist and then show that they must be equal.

Question:
Contradiction is Disproving Negation:

When we are proving an implication by assuming it to be false and then showing a contradiction, are we just disproving the negation of the implication? 

Thank you!
Answer: Yes. To prove $$A\Rightarrow B$$ by contradiction, we assume $$A$$ and, as an extra assumption, assume $$\neg B$$. If $$\neg B$$ is false, then $$B$$ must be true.

Question:
Q22: I am unable to proceed with the problem.
Can anyone please help me with the solution and guide me on how to proceed.
Answer:
you can use the definition of divisibility directly to rewrite $$a\mid b\land b\mid a$$ and see what you get

also you can try using the bounds by divisibility theorem

This might not be of much help but I think to prove it the first way, you can say (using the definition of divisibility) that since a divides b, there exists some integer k that when multiplied with a, yields b. And in the same way you can say that since b divides a, there exists some integer k’ that when multiplied with b yields a. And then using this fact you can substitute a with b (k’) into your second equation, and you should get b(k)(k’)=b. And then divide both sides by b, and you get k(k’)=1. Which means the only possible integers that work are 1 and -1, and that means if you look back at the first two statements that say a(k)=b and b(k’)=a then a has to be +/- b.

Question: Application of induction: I was looking through the notes and we are using POMI when the domain of variable is $$\mathbb{N}$$, but is it applicable when the domain is $$\mathbb{Z}$$ or $$\mathbb{Q}$$?
Answer:
Regular induction only works for "well-behaved" sets (leaving it vague on purpose). There are other types of induction such as transfinite induction, structural induction and real induction which work for more general structures.

tl;dr any domain you want to use induction with must have a least element but that's not a sufficient condition.
Regular induction only works for well-ordered sets. You can look into those online if you're interested. There are other types of induction such as transfinite induction, structural induction and real induction which work for more general structures.

tl;dr any domain you want to use induction with must have a least element but that's not a sufficient condition.
Regular induction only works for well-ordered sets. You can look into those online if you're interested. There are other types of induction such as transfinite induction, structural induction and real induction which work for more general structures.

You really don't need to split this into cases. $$k = 3$$ would work for any three consecutive integers. What you should do is show that 3 divides one of these three for any $$a$$.

Question:
Disproving nested quantifiers:

From EP3, Question 11 d)

For statements of this form, are we allowed to find a value of m where there is no possible value of n that satisfies the condition? For example, consider m=0. Then 0<0 is false no matter what value of n you pick, so there is no single value of n that works for all values of m. I'm not sure if this is valid reasoning due to the order of the quantifiers. The other way I would consider disproving this statement is proving the negation.
Answer:
I would say that your suggestion is valid, since as you pointed out every natural number multiplied by 0 is 0 and 0 < 0 is false. This still works for the order of the quantifiers since you proved there cannot be an n where for all m the statement is true. I feel like it's more important to understand what the quantifiers are saying rather than focus purely on their order, so you should be okay with your reasoning. 
Essentially your argument is what you would use to prove the negation is true.  No many what value of $$n$$ we consider we could always choose $$m=0$$ to give $$-nm \geq 0$$.

Question:
Quick Question:

Just checking that for a question like this, can we start the proof with

let x be a real number, so the equation: x^2 - 6x + 9 = (x-3)^2 >= 0. Then we just rearrange and explain. I just want to confirm we can sorta just start with the left hand side of what we are trying to prove
Answer:
This is the proper way to do it. I would order it a little differently though:

Let $$x \in \mathbb{R}$$. We know that $$(x-3)^2 \geq 0$$ since the square of any real number is non-negative. This means that $$x^2 - 6x + 9 \geq 0 \implies x^2 + 9 \geq 6x$$, which is what we wanted to prove.

Question:
General Questions for Test 1:

1. Will we be tested on definitions, such as the definition of a proof, a proposition, etc.

2. Do we need to have the trig identities memorized or will they be given?

3. if we were to include the "discovery" process in the proof, would we lose marks?

4. could the "try the following" questions show up on the test or are they just extensions (i.e. too complicated) for the tests?
Answer:
1.  You will not be required to state definitions.  That being said, it is really important to know the definitions of terms and symbols in this course. 

2.  I would say for MATH 135 that you should know the Pythagorean Identity, the sum rules and the double angle formulas.

3.  You won't lose marks for including the discovery process but it does clutter up your proof.  I would encourage you to keep it off to the side. 

4.  You will not be expected to regurgitate any proofs that you have already seen.   That being said, understanding proofs gives you insight for proving other similar statements.

Question:
MA04 Practice:

The question was asking what the open sentence would be. Isn't an open sentence, p(n), not supposed to contain any quantifiers? I am confused on this.
Answer:
Open sentences may contain quantifiers. For example "P(n): for any real x, x+n^2<  x+n^3". It is open because the truth value is not definite and it depends on $$n$$. That's why we denote it by P(n), in which $$n$$ is the free variable.

General examples: "P(x, y, z): x+y+z>0", "P(y, z): for all x such that 0<x<5, x+y+z>0".

Open sentences may contain quantifiers. For example "P(n): for any real x, x+n^2<  x+n^3". It is open because the truth value is not definite and it depends on $$n$$. That's why we denote it by P(n), in which $$n$$ is the free variable. Open sentences may contain quantifiers. For example "P(n): for any real x, x+n^2<  x+n^3". Question: Difference between set builder notations type 1 and type 2?: When I was reviewing set builder notations,  both type 1 and type 2 seemed interchangeable to me. For example, {n∈N: n|12} (type 1) wont it be the same logically as {n|12: n∈N} (type 2)?
Answer: No. The latter isn't valid set builder notation (as defined in this course), because $$n\mid 12$$ is not a function. It's actually a relation, which is almost a function, but not every input to a relation need have a unique output (in this case, note that if $$n\mid 12$$ then $$n\mid 24$$ always follows, so $$12$$ and $$24$$ are both valid outputs for $$n$$ in this relation).

Question:
Question About WA3 Q3(a):

For WA3 Q3(a), we have a following statement,

∀a, b ∈ N, (3a | (4b − 1) ∧ a | (12b + 7)) ⇒ ((a = 1) ∨ (b = 5))

However, I have confusion in terms of assuming hypothesis.

When we say assume the hypothesis is true:

   1. Are we saying literally all a and b values satisfies "(3a | (4b − 1) ∧ a | (12b + 7))" this open sentence or,

   2. it means assume that a and b are values such that "(3a | (4b − 1) ∧ a | (12b + 7))" this open sentence becomes true.

For what I think, 2 is true and that's why at the end of solution, among 4 possible values of a, we check if any of them contradict our assumption of hypothesis.

Thanks for your feedback!
Answer:
-Additional Question-

Also, I understand, a=2 and a=10 are impossible as they contradict the assumption of hypothesis we made first. Since 2 and 10 are impossible, do they make whole statement false or they just make conclusion false (as a = 2 or a= 10 means a is neither 1 or 5) hence make whole statement false?

Also, I understand, a=2 and a=10 are impossible as they contradict the assumption of hypothesis we made first. Since 2 and 10 are impossible, do they make whole statement false or they just make hypothesis false hence make whole implication true?

Your second understanding is correct. 

We are trying to prove that for all natural numbers $$a$$ and $$b$$ if the hypothesis is true, then the conclusion is true.  So we assume that we have two arbitrary natural numbers $$a$$ and $$b$$ which make the hypothesis true.  Then our goal is to show that the conclusion is also true for these values.  

If you choose $$a=2$$, then if the hypothesis is true we would have that $$6 \mid (4b-1)$$ and $$2 \mid (12b+7)$$.  It turns out that this would actually be impossible for any $$b$$ we choose because $$4b-1$$ is odd (And also $$12b+7)$$ and 6 is even.  We can't have an even integer dividing an odd integer.

Question:
EP5 Q9:

How to prove this is unique? 

But before proving it, I am curious how the set T be a unique set for every set S. Let S={0, 1, 2, 3}, then set T can be {0} or {0, 1, 2} or any set that is a subset of S. 

-------

Also Q8 for EP5, can I just provide a counter-example to disprove it? I saw another post but I just want to clarify.
Answer:
Notice that the uniqueness of $$T$$ comes before $$S$$ in the statement.  So you are trying to find a unique set $$T$$ that works for every set $$S$$.  (The way you are understanding the statement is for every set $$S$$,  there is a unique set $$T$$... and as you pointed out this would be false.   The order of quantifiers matters!)

Q8:  This is a universally quantified statement.  If you want to disprove it, you give a counterexample.

Question:
EP3 Question 17:

"Prove that the product of any four consecutive integers is one less than a perfect square".

We can represent this as:

For all integers n, there exists a positive integer m such that n(n+1)(n+2)(n+3) = m^2-1


So can we prove this using mathematical induction on n where the P(n): n(n+1)(n+2)(n+3) = m^2-1? Or is there a better/accurate of way of doing it as it is a chapter 3 question?
Answer:
There is a clever way to factorize n(n+1)(n+2)(n+3)+1, try partially expanding some terms and make it a whole square of something
You may also find it simpler to work with $$(n-1)n(n+1)(n+2)+1$$ and see if you can write this as a perfect square with some clever factoring.

Question:
EP5-Q4:

Can I prove Q4 of EP5 like this? 

1. Can I say $$x\in A \vee x\notin A\equiv x\in U(universe)$$?

2. Also, for (ii), can I just say this is reversible, so it is similar prove with (i)?
Answer:
I think you have made this direction much more complicated then you need to.  All elements are in the universe so you can just jump from $$x \in A \cup \overline{A}$$ to $$x \in \mathcal{U}$$ directly. 

To prove the reverse direction,  I would consider $$x \in \mathcal{U}$$.  Then I would consider two cases:  $$x \in A$$ and $$x \notin A$$.  In both cases, you can show that $$x \in A \cup \overline{A}$$.

This approach would avoid the difficulties you are facing.
